Topic.Title: Conservatives once ridiculed Ayn Rand

Message.Msg: Good post. I'm glad to see so many intellectuals agree with me. It's just lamentable that no one mentioned that in Ayn Rand's world, the only way most of her self-interested women can "give themselves" to a man is to be raped. They are far too self-absorbed to think about mutual pleasure. I wonder if Ayn was a submissive or a dominator, a masochist or sadist? What I can't understand is how they got Gary Cooper to "rape" Patricia Neal in the 1949 film version of "The Fountainhead." But it WAS just after the incredible violence of WW2 and alsop, perhaps the stars were short of cash or wanted to be seen as "edgy." This rampant rapism is true even though the railroad baroness Dagny Taggart has a torrid affair with Francisco Domingo Carlos Andres Sebastian d’Anconia (I had forgotten his name but who wouldn't?), apparently because she is so enthralled by his cocktail-party repartee about how money is the root of all good. Since it ran to something like 63 pages in my paperback edition, I wouldn't be surprised if he had NEVER been invited to another cocktail party. Anyway, that was before Dagny met John Galt, the spiritual leader of her leaderless brave new economic world. Small wonder the film versions of Parts 1 and 2 were flops. Ayn Rand's laissez-faire capitalism works. The invisible hand of the marketplace ran them out of town.

Topic.Title: Am I to understand that I will be slandered and taunted until I leave Boeing message board?

Message.Msg: Slandered and taunted? Awfully full of yourself, don't you think? You repeatedly post things that are, at best, highly inaccurate, others that are patently false, others that are outright lies and still others that are just ridiculous, apparently in some vain attempt to paint Boeing in an unflattering light because of the mountain-sized chip on your shoulder. As a result, you have no credibility, not on this board and certainly not with me. You then complain when people try to set the record straight and criticize you for being a douche bag. You bring it on yourself and have nobody to blame but the guy in the mirror, but you clearly get some kind of sick reward for doing so however or you wouldn't continue to do it. You know, there are plenty of genuine, factually accurate things to be critical of Boeing, its executives and senior management about. There's really no need to make stuff up. As for Airbus ... I know people who have worked for Airbus and have a close friend who did for several years until just recently when she decided to go back to college to get her Phd. Airbus has its own problems and really isn't the flawless machine you like to portray them as. Finally, I have a job at Boeing that I enjoy, that pays me more money than I ever imagined I'd make, with pretty darn good benefits, certainly more than what most people get, working with some really great people, doing fun and interesting things on an almost daily basis that most people never get an opportunity to do. You do not. It's a shame you threw it all away and are now on the outside looking in, unable to let go, unable to accept responsibility for your actions and unable to just move on. You are a bitter, angry, little man, swimming in a sea of misery due to a massive personal problem with no solution anywhere in sight. I am so glad I'm not you.

Message.Title: Snowden’s Email Provider Shuts Down
Message.Msg: John Keller Lew Rockwell Blog August 9, 2013 Texas-based Lavabit posted a cryptic message as their homepage and has shutdown service. This is the provider that Edward Snowden supposedly used, so it doesn’t take much imagination to guess that some unholy alliance of the NSA, FBI, CIA, and some other alphabet-soup star-chamber despots served them papers including a gag-order. Here is the message in full (emphasis mine): My Fellow Users, I have been forced to make a difficult decision: to become complicit in crimes against the American people or walk away from nearly ten years of hard work by shutting down Lavabit. After significant soul searching, I have decided to suspend operations. I wish that I could legally share with you the events that led to my decision. I cannot. I feel you deserve to know what’s going on–the first amendment is supposed to guarantee me the freedom to speak out in situations like this. Unfortunately, Congress has passed laws that say otherwise. As things currently stand, I cannot share my experiences over the last six weeks, even though I have twice made the appropriate requests. What’s going to happen now? We’ve already started preparing the paperwork needed to continue to fight for the Constitution in the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals. A favorable decision would allow me resurrect Lavabit as an American company. This experience has taught me one very important lesson: without congressional action or a strong judicial precedent, I would _strongly_ recommend against anyone trusting their private data to a company with physical ties to the United States. Sincerely, Ladar Levison Owner and Operator, Lavabit LLC

Topic.Title: The Best time in Human history happened without a Federal Reserve and No IRS.

Message.Msg: And there were bank panics on a regular basis: 19th century Panic of 1819, a U.S. recession with bank failures; culmination of U.S.'s first boom-to-bust economic cycle Panic of 1825, a pervasive British recession in which many banks failed, nearly including the Bank of England Panic of 1837, a U.S. recession with bank failures, followed by a 5-year depression Panic of 1847, United Kingdom Panic of 1857, a U.S. recession with bank failures Panic of 1866, Europe Panic of 1873, a U.S. recession with bank failures, followed by a 4-year depression Panic of 1884, United States and Europe Panic of 1890, mainly affecting the United Kingdom and Argentina Panic of 1893, a U.S. recession with bank failures Australian banking crisis of 1893 20th century Panic of 1907, a U.S. economic recession with bank failures Great Depression, the worst systemic banking crisis of the 20th century People grew weary of losing their money and demanded more stability hence the Federal Reserve, oh wait they had a Federal Reserve in 1930 it's just that under Hoover and Carnegie they thought their job was to keep the supply of money low. That didn't work out very well, hence the modern version that took us through the time when the U.S. became THE economic superpower of the world but it reverted to a free market model under Greenspan, that didn't work out very well.

Message.Title: you missed Tesla now pay attention Elon Musk on the Hyperloop, August 12 , 2013 start reading, sell Boeing
Message.Msg: The fevered speculation about billionaire entrepreneur Elon Musk's mysterious "Hyperloop" transport system is about to come to an end. Musk, the visionary behind electric-car firm Tesla and the private spaceflight company SpaceX, has said he will unveil a Hyperloop design on Monday (Aug. 12), after teasing the world about the superfast travel technology for more than a year. The solar-powered Hyperloop would allow passengers to get from Los Angeles to San Francisco in less than 30 minutes, Musk has said, meaning it must travel at speeds greater than 600 mph (966 km/h). The system would be cheap and convenient, he added, with tickets costing less than a seat aboard a plane or train and Hyperloop vehicles departing frequently from their various stations. Though we don't know exactly how the Hyperloop will work or what it will look like, Musk has dropped some hints since first disclosing the concept in July 2012. For example, this past May he described the Hyperloop as a "cross between a Concorde and a railgun and an air hockey table."

Message.Title: Executive Orders to protect black school childred from discipline. Obama is a racist
Message.Msg: Obama Tells Teachers Not To Reprimand Black Pres. Obama is asking public school teachers to “take it easy” on black students who misbehave. On July 26, 2012, Obama signed an Executive Order to create the African American Education Initiative. The order births a new federal bureaucracy and effectively offers black students a green light to misbehave at school. Advertisement Obama asked public school teachers to reduce the number of disciplinary actions taken against black students. Specifically, it calls on schools to “not rely on methods that result in disparate use of disciplinary tools.” The order, however, does not include any suggestions to improve black students’ inappropriate behavior. Members of the new bureaucracy will work to pressure public school systems into complying with the president’s order. To do that, public schools must utilize a quota system. That’s right, a quota system. The U.S. Department of Justice’s Bureau of Justice Statistics reports, “There is a huge crime rate disparity between blacks and other racial groups.” So, wouldn’t it make sense that black students were discipline more frequently? DOJ’s report shows that homicide rates in black communities are nine times higher than in white communities. Subsequently, 93 percent of black homicide victims are killed by black perpetrators. But Obama argues that disciplining black students isn’t fair because they “lack equal access” to quality education. Let’s look at the facts. Washington, D.C. spends the highest amount on average per student of any U.S. state or territory. D.C. public schools also “educate” more black students than anywhere else in the country. Despite D.C.’s “overfunding” public schools, they are “widely touted as the worst performing schools in the entire industrialized world.” Obama’s motives for this initiative are clearly flawed but isn't it flawed in every aspect of his p

Topic.Title: slow start to August

Message.Msg: Maybe with all the new products coming they need to open up more lines for the 737 and 787. We have a little while for the tanker. Maybe the lack of air activity is due to additional and perhaps redundant quality checks and the effect of the Honeywell story. Boeing needs to reduce their backlog and have shorter delivery schedules. If that means more lines, than so be it. Waiting 5-7 years for some new planes if ridiculous. More lines---address customer delivery requirements better. A penny saved could lose market share by not being robust enough with delivery. Think of Northrop in WWII spitting out those planes daily at an incredible rate. Its possible.

Topic.Title: slow start to August

Message.Msg: Rumor has it that there are quality issues with the Charleston planes.

Topic.Title: slow start to August

Message.Msg: It appears that the delivery issues have nothing to do with either production or quality issues. It seems that has more to do with cutomers and delivery dates. There are 737 first flights every day. The planes sitting on the flight line in Charleston are there due to customer issues. These seem to be almost over. July started slow and finished up quite well. So I believe that these isues will start to fade in the last of August/ start of September. Only time will tell.

Topic.Title: The Best time in Human history happened without a Federal Reserve and No IRS.

Message.Msg: WRONG, the worst inflations in our history occured in the 1740s, 1780s, 1790s, 1815, 1865, 1920s with lots of deflation in between. Fun times 20%+ inflation followed by deflation. Much worse inflation than the worst in the post Fed period during the early 1970s and there were no deflationary years except possibly 2008 after the Greenspan debacle.

Message.Title: Letter from Boeing today
Message.Msg: I opened it with gleeful anticipation. This would be the invite and tickets to the Family Day. Hey! whats this, its not tickets but its an invite. An invite to give them my email address and they promise to send me news releases on whats happening. Well if that don't just take the cake. Listen James or whoever is running that place I have a pretty read on whats going on up there, in fact if you follow my post, you will find out things that you didn't know. You could let us know what those technical issues are that the 787's keep returning to field for. Hope those tickets get here soon.
